narrative=Sarah Graham, a 71-year-old retired geophysicist with a disability, was last seen at a community center where she frequently engaged in volunteer work. She was known for participating in organized protests, and just prior to her disappearance, she left behind her passport and important documents. Her son, Mohammed Bowen, expressed concerns when she did not return from their planned visit to East Mains, Ormiston, EH35 5NG, a popular vacation spot they enjoyed. Further investigation revealed that she might have boarded a ferry, an activity unusual given her regular routine. Authorities speculated she intended to visit a nearby fairground but veered off course. Sarah was later located safely on Rose Street, Edinburgh by police.

narrative=Sarah Graham, known to participate in organized protests, was last seen in an urban area near Dean Road, Bo'ness. Her friend, Annette King, reported that Sarah had left her passport and essential documents at home. Concerns grew when suggestions arose of her involvement at a cult location. Police, following several leads, eventually traced her to an address on Cluny Drive, Edinburgh, safe but disoriented.

narrative=Sarah Graham, a 71-year-old retired geophysicist, was reported missing after she failed to return home from a planned outing in Edinburgh. Last seen at a neighborhood cafe, she was on her way to volunteer work at a local urban center when she vanished. Her estrangement from relatives left few immediate contacts aware of her movements. Sarah's daughter soon realized that her mother had left behind crucial identification documents and her passport, raising alarms about her well-being. Despite the initial high-risk assessment, exhaustive police efforts led to her being traced to a vacation spot just off 55 Eastfield, Edinburgh. While the exact reasons for her disappearance remain uncertain, authorities speculate a voluntary break from routine life.

narrative=Sarah Graham was last seen leaving her sister's home at 14 St Andrew Street, EH22 1AN. Concern arose when it was suspected she was possibly involved in a cult near Knox Place, Haddington, EH41 4EB, prompting a search in that area.

narrative=Sarah Graham, a retired geophysicist estranged from her relatives, was reported missing from her home. It's believed that she was linked to an organized protest taking place in Edinburgh, possibly near 1 Constitution Place, Leith Docks. Witnesses suggest that Sarah, despite her age and disability, was seen at the location, actively participating in the protest. Her sisters, distanced by past disagreements, were unaware of her activities. Furthermore, there is a possibility that Sarah boarded a ferry shortly after the protest, although this remains unconfirmed. This potential boarding could explain the inability to locate her until traced by police to a different address in Edinburgh, 66 Mount Vernon Road, after several days missing.

narrative=Sarah Graham, a 72-year-old retired geophysicist, was reported missing after failing to meet a friend at a library visit in Edinburgh. Known for her independence despite her disability, Sarah's sudden absence raised concerns. She left behind her passport and important documents at 1 Tanfield, Edinburgh, a detail that puzzled her friends and family. Her sister, Jane Graham, noted that Sarah had mentioned a visit to an old acquaintance in Livingston but never specified where. Emergency contacts, including her son Daniel Blake, joined the search efforts. Eventually, Sarah was located safely at a friend's home on Bernard Terrace, confirming she had indeed visited Houston Mains in Livingston. Her disappearance seemed to be a mix-up in travel plans, causing undue worry among her loved ones.

narrative=Sarah Graham was last seen at the bustling fairground near 91,93 Princes Street, Edinburgh. She had visited with her sister, who momentarily stepped away to purchase tickets for a ride. When her sister returned, Sarah was nowhere to be found. Concerned for her sister’s safety, given Sarah’s age and known disability, she immediately notified fairground staff, who conducted a search of the area. Despite their efforts, Sarah was not located at the time. Later, she was traced to 4 Priory Gate, safe and sound, by local police. It seemed that, disoriented by the noise and crowd, Sarah had wandered away, unknowingly exiting the fairground and heading towards quieter streets nearby.
